items.title: UK police charge man with attempted murder after mass stabbing attack on train
items.standfirst: UK police on Monday charged a man with attempted murder after a violent knife attack on a train Saturday evening left 11 people wounded. The three-minute long stabbing spree left passengers traumatised as they ran through carriages to get away from the attacker before the train made an emergency stop.
items.content: UK police on Monday charged a man with attempted murder after a violent knife attack on a train Saturday evening left 11 people wounded. The three-minute long stabbing spree left passengers traumatised as they ran through carriages to get away from the attacker before the train made an emergency stop.

items.standfirst: A powerful, 6.3 magnitude earthquake shook northern Afghanistan before dawn Monday, killing at least 20 people and injuring more than 300 others, a health official said. FRANCE 24's Shahzaib Wahlah has more from the region.

items.title: At least 20 killed as magnitude-6.3 earthquake strikes northern Afghanistan
items.standfirst: A magnitude 6.3 earthquake struck northern Afghanistan overnight Sunday into Monday, killing more than 20 people and injuring more than 500, provincial officials said. The quake, at a depth of 28km (17 miles) near Mazar-i-Sharif, hit just two months after a tremor in the east killed more than 2,200.
items.content: A magnitude 6.3 earthquake struck northern Afghanistan overnight Sunday into Monday, killing more than 20 people and injuring more than 500, provincial officials said. clusters.title: Israel confirms return of three hostages’ remains from Gaza

items.title: Israel confirms return of three hostages’ remains from Gaza
items.standfirst: Israel has identified the remains of three army officers returned from Gaza, all killed in the October 7 attacks. Their return brings to 20 the total number of bodies released by Hamas since the mid-October ceasefire. Israel has criticized Hamas for the slow pace of returns, while the group says difficult conditions in Gaza are hindering recovery efforts.
items.content: Israel has identified the remains of three army officers returned from Gaza, all killed in the October 7 attacks. Their return brings to 20 the total number of bodies released by Hamas since the mid-October ceasefire. Israel has criticized Hamas for the slow pace of returns, while the group says difficult conditions in Gaza are hindering recovery efforts.

items.title: Israel confirms remains handed over by Hamas belong to three hostages
items.standfirst: Israel confirmed on Monday that remains handed over by Hamas belonged to three Israeli military officers who had been taken captive by the group on October 7, 2023 and held in the Gaza Strip. Hamas has so far returned 20 surviving hostages and the remains of 20 others as part of an ongoing ceasefire deal with Israel.

items.title: Mexican mayor killed during Day of the Dead celebrations
items.standfirst: A mayor in Mexico ’s western state of Michoacan was shot dead in a plaza in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities said. Local politicians in Mexico are frequently victims of political and organized crime violence.
items.content: A mayor in Mexico ’s western state of Michoacan was shot dead in a plaza in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities said. Local politicians in Mexico are frequently victims of political and organized crime violence.

items.title: Mexican mayor killed during Day of the Dead celebrations in Michoacan
items.standfirst: The mayor of the Uruapan municipality, in the western state of Michoacan, was gunned down Saturday night in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities said.
items.content: The mayor of the Uruapan municipality, in the western state of Michoacan, was gunned down Saturday night in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities said.(Image credit: Eduardo Verdugo)

items.title: Calls for justice after Mexico mayor killed during Day of the Dead festival
items.standfirst: Carlos Manzo, an outspoken critic of organised crime, was shot dead during a public festival in the city of Uruapan.
items.content: Carlos Manzo, an outspoken critic of organised crime, was shot dead during a public festival in the city of Uruapan.

items.title: Mexican mayor killed during Day of the Dead celebrations
items.standfirst: Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, who was under police protection, was shot dead in front of dozens of peopleA mayor in Mexico’s western state of Michoacán was shot dead in a plaza in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities have said.The mayor of the Uruapan municipality, Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, was gunned down Saturday night in the town’s historic centre. He was rushed to a hospital where he later died, according to state prosecutor Carlos Torres Piña. Continue reading...
items.content: Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, who was under police protection, was shot dead in front of dozens of peopleA mayor in Mexico’s western state of Michoacán was shot dead in a plaza in front of dozens of people who had gathered for Day of the Dead festivities, authorities have said.The mayor of the Uruapan municipality, Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez, was gunned down Saturday night in the town’s historic centre. He was rushed to a hospital where he later died, according to state prosecutor Carlos Torres Piña. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A mayor in Michoacan, Mexico, was shot dead during Day of the Dead festivities.
The mayor was killed in the city of Uruapan in front of dozens of people.
Carlos Alberto Manzo Rodríguez was the mayor of the Uruapan municipality.
The mayor was under police protection at the time of the shooting.
The mayor was an outspoken critic of organized crime in the area.

clusters.title: New York mayoral race: On the campaign trail with Zohran Mamdani
clusters.neutral_headline: New York Mayoral Race: Zohran Mamdani on the Campaign Trail

items.title: New York mayoral race: On the campaign trail with Zohran Mamdani
items.standfirst: Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic candidate in New York City's mayoral race, is shaking up US politics. The 34-year-old could make history on Tuesday by becoming the city's first Muslim and South Asian mayor. His Socialist policies have electrified younger voters, while frightening conservatives and the old guard of the Democratic Party. Can a socialist stand up to US President Donald Trump and win? Our correspondents Jessica Le Masurier and Yves Schaeffner followed Mamdani on the campaign trail.
items.content: Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic candidate in New York City's mayoral race, is shaking up US politics. The 34-year-old could make history on Tuesday by becoming the city's first Muslim and South Asian mayor. His Socialist policies have electrified younger voters, while frightening conservatives and the old guard of the Democratic Party. Can a socialist stand up to US President Donald Trump and win? Our correspondents Jessica Le Masurier and Yves Schaeffner followed Mamdani on the campaign trail.

items.title: The president who cried tariffs: will the US supreme court challenge Trump’s trade war?
items.standfirst: The US high court will hear arguments on whether Trump’s erratic imposition of global tariffs is legally validDonald Trump thrives on emergencies. He cried havoc on the very first day of his second term, declaring a national emergency caused by an “invasion” of “illegal aliens” from Mexico. He has since invoked emergencies more than any president since the passage of the National Emergencies Act in 1976.Next Wednesday, he faces another of his own making, as the US supreme court hears oral arguments on whether his globe-shaking signature economic policy – tariffs – is legally valid. Continue reading...
items.content: The US high court will hear arguments on whether Trump’s erratic imposition of global tariffs is legally validDonald Trump thrives on emergencies. He cried havoc on the very first day of his second term, declaring a national emergency caused by an “invasion” of “illegal aliens” from Mexico. He has since invoked emergencies more than any president since the passage of the National Emergencies Act in 1976.Next Wednesday, he faces another of his own making, as the US supreme court hears oral arguments on whether his globe-shaking signature economic policy – tariffs – is legally valid. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Supreme Court will hear a case on Trump's tariffs.
The case will decide the fate of Trump's signature economic policy.
The tariffs have been used to reshape the global order.
The case is the latest involving Trump's agenda.
Arguments will be heard on whether tariffs are legally valid.

items.title: Hackers and Crime Rings Are Teaming Up to Steal Cargo, Cyber Firm Says
Hackers and Crime Rings Are Teaming Up to Steal Cargo, Cyber Firm Says
items.standfirst: Hackers are infiltrating trucking and freight companies in a scheme to steal and sell cargo shipments, a growing campaign that could end up costing companies and consumers billions of dollars, according to new cybersecurity research.
items.content: Hackers are infiltrating trucking and freight companies in a scheme to steal and sell cargo shipments, a growing campaign that could end up costing companies and consumers billions of dollars, according to new cybersecurity research.

ai_summary: Hackers are infiltrating trucking and freight companies.
The goal is to steal and sell cargo shipments.
The campaign could cost companies and consumers billions.
The information comes from new cybersecurity research.
The hackers are working with crime rings.

items.content: Movement for family and humanitarian reasons continued to rise in 2024

ai_summary: The OECD reported a sharp fall in work-related migration.
Movement for family and humanitarian reasons rose in 2024.
The report covers migration to rich countries.
The data was released by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
The report focuses on migration trends.

clusters.title: Sinner wins Paris Masters to reclaim world No 1 ranking from Alcaraz
clusters.neutral_headline: Sinner Reclaims World Number One Ranking With Paris Masters Win

items.title: Sinner wins Paris Masters to reclaim world No 1 ranking from Alcaraz
items.standfirst: Jannik Sinner's first Paris Masters crown moves the Italian past Carlos Alcaraz and back into the ATP's top spot.
items.content: Jannik Sinner's first Paris Masters crown moves the Italian past Carlos Alcaraz and back into the ATP's top spot.

items.title: Sinner reclaims world number one ranking with Paris Masters win
items.standfirst: 24-year-old Jannik Sinner won the Paris Masters for the first time on Sunday by defeating Felix Auger-Aliassime. The Italian's maiden crown in Paris will see Sinner return to the pinnacle of men's tennis when the ATP rankings are updated on Monday.
items.content: 24-year-old Jannik Sinner won the Paris Masters for the first time on Sunday by defeating Felix Auger-Aliassime. The Italian's maiden crown in Paris will see Sinner return to the pinnacle of men's tennis when the ATP rankings are updated on Monday.

ai_summary: Jannik Sinner won the Paris Masters on Sunday.
Sinner defeated Felix Auger-Aliassime in the final.
The win will move Sinner to the top of the ATP rankings.
Sinner is 24 years old.
This is Sinner's first Paris Masters title.

items.title: President Trump's extended 60 Minutes interview
items.standfirst: President Trump sat down with Norah O'Donnell to discuss U.S.-China relations, Venezuela, Israel, the government shutdown, immigration, the National Guard and more.
items.content: President Trump sat down with Norah O'Donnell to discuss U.S.-China relations, Venezuela, Israel, the government shutdown, immigration, the National Guard and more.

items.title: President Donald Trump's extended 60 Minutes interview
items.standfirst: Norah O'Donnell sat down with President Donald J. Trump at Mar-a-Lago to discuss U.S.-China relations, Venezuela, Israel, the government shutdown, immigration, the National Guard and more. Editor's note: The video above is an extended version of the interview that was broadcast on 60 Minutes on Sunday, November 2, 2025. This extended version was condensed for clarity.
items.content: Norah O'Donnell sat down with President Donald J. Trump at Mar-a-Lago to discuss U.S.-China relations, Venezuela, Israel, the government shutdown, immigration, the National Guard and more. items.title: Trump on nuclear testing, the government shutdown, immigration and tariffs
items.standfirst: Watch as President Trump discusses testing nuclear weapons, U.S.-China relations, Israel, the government shutdown, immigration, tariffs, and whether he'll try to stay in the White House beyond 2028.
items.content: Watch as President Trump discusses testing nuclear weapons, U.S.-China relations, Israel, the government shutdown, immigration, tariffs, and whether he'll try to stay in the White House beyond 2028.

items.title: Trump pressed on government shutdown, nuclear weapons testing, ICE raids
items.standfirst: In his first sit-down interview with 60 Minutes in five years, President Trump spoke about the government shutdown, Russia, the Middle East and other key issues.
items.content: In his first sit-down interview with 60 Minutes in five years, President Trump spoke about the government shutdown, Russia, the Middle East and other key issues.

items.title: Trump says Xi assured him China won’t take action on Taiwan
items.standfirst: US president claims Beijing won't act on Taiwan while Trump is in the White House, 'because they know the consequences'.
items.content: US president claims Beijing won't act on Taiwan while Trump is in the White House, 'because they know the consequences'.

items.title: Trump: China knows the consequences of military action in Taiwan
items.standfirst: In an exclusive 60 Minutes interview with Norah O'Donnell, President Trump said Chinese President Xi Jinping understands the consequences of taking military action against Taiwan.
items.content: In an exclusive 60 Minutes interview with Norah O'Donnell, President Trump said Chinese President Xi Jinping understands the consequences of taking military action against Taiwan.

ai_summary: President Trump discussed U.S.-China relations in the 60 Minutes interview.
The interview covered Venezuela, Israel, and the government shutdown.
Immigration, tariffs, and the National Guard were also discussed.
Trump said Xi Jinping understands the consequences of action on Taiwan.
The interview was conducted by Norah O'Donnell at Mar-a-Lago.

clusters.title: Israel warns of intensifying attacks in Lebanon against Hezbollah
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Warns of Intensifying Attacks Against Hezbollah in Lebanon

items.title: Israel warns of intensifying attacks in Lebanon against Hezbollah
items.standfirst: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned Beirut on Sunday to disarm Iran-backed Hezbollah, signalling that Israel could intensify operations in Lebanon against the militant group. Despite a November 2024 ceasefire with Hezbollah, Israel maintains troops in five areas in southern Lebanon and has kept up regular strikes.
items.content: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned Beirut on Sunday to disarm Iran-backed Hezbollah, signalling that Israel could intensify operations in Lebanon against the militant group. Despite a November 2024 ceasefire with Hezbollah, Israel maintains troops in five areas in southern Lebanon and has kept up regular strikes.

items.title: Israel threatens to step up attacks against Hezbollah in Lebanon
items.standfirst: Israel’s defence minister accuses Beirut of delaying efforts to disarm militant group a day after deadly Israeli airstrikeIsrael has threatened to step up its attacks against Hezbollah in southern Lebanon, a day after the Lebanese health ministry reported that four people had been killed in an Israeli airstrike.Despite the November 2024 ceasefire, Israel maintains troops in five areas in southern Lebanon and has kept up regular strikes. Continue reading...
items.content: Israel’s defence minister accuses Beirut of delaying efforts to disarm militant group a day after deadly Israeli airstrikeIsrael has threatened to step up its attacks against Hezbollah in southern Lebanon, a day after the Lebanese health ministry reported that four people had been killed in an Israeli airstrike.Despite the November 2024 ceasefire, Israel maintains troops in five areas in southern Lebanon and has kept up regular strikes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Israel's Prime Minister warned Beirut to disarm Hezbollah, signaling potential escalation.
Israel maintains troops in five areas in southern Lebanon despite a November ceasefire.
Regular Israeli strikes continue, despite the existing ceasefire agreement with Hezbollah.
The Israeli Defence Minister accused Beirut of delaying efforts to disarm Hezbollah.
A recent Israeli airstrike resulted in the reported deaths of four people.

clusters.title: Avalanche in Italy kills five including father and daughter
clusters.neutral_headline: Avalanche in Italy Kills Five German Mountaineers

items.title: Avalanche in Italy kills five including father and daughter
items.standfirst: Authorities say the five mountaineers who died while scaling Cima Vertana are German.
items.content: Authorities say the five mountaineers who died while scaling Cima Vertana are German.

items.title: Five mountaineers die after avalanche in Italy
items.standfirst: Five German mountaineers have died in an avalanche in northern Italy.
items.content: Five German mountaineers have died in an avalanche in northern Italy.

ai_summary: An avalanche in northern Italy resulted in the deaths of five mountaineers.
The deceased mountaineers were identified as German citizens.
The incident occurred while the mountaineers were scaling Cima Vertana.
Authorities confirmed the deaths of the five mountaineers in the avalanche.
The avalanche took place in the Italian Alps, claiming five lives.
